titleStmt.title: Perceived financial affluence predicts decisions to exert effort in reward pursuit

affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychology Social Neuroscience Lab Pusan

analytic.title: Perceived financial affluence predicts decisions to exert effort in reward pursuit

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The willingness to exert effort is essential for gaining something of value. Perceptions of one's financial states, whether affluent or scarce, are thought to be closely linked to motivated behavior in pursuing effortful yet rewarding outcomes. However, direct experimental evidence for this relationship has been limited. To address this gap, we employed an effort-based decision-making paradigm where participants chose between solving easy, low-reward problems and difficult, high-reward problems (n = 192), to assess their willingness to exert effort for potential rewards. We found that participants who perceive themselves to be more financially affluent were more likely to choose difficult yet high-reward problems, resulting in greater monetary gains. This pattern persisted across different domains and remained significant after accounting for potential confounding individual differences. The availability of nonfinancial resources, such as perceived social support, showed no positive correlation with the choices of difficult problems. Furthermore, participants with greater financial affluence reported significantly lower levels of performance-related anxiety, contributing to their increased choices of difficult problems. Together, by revealing the robust relationship between the perceived financial affluence, willingness to pursue challenging goals, and the resulting outcomes, the present study suggests a possible mechanism underlying the self-reinforcing cycle of wealth and achievement.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The willingness to exert effort is essential, particularly when pursuing challenging goals for valuable outcomes. Perceptions of one's financial affluence can play a significant role in this process, as financial states affect attitudes towards uncertainty and the valuation of future rewards [1][2][3] . These challenging goals, which demand greater effort, are highly valued for their potential to yield greater rewards, thus motivating individuals to strive for their desired goals [4][5][6][7] . Notably, the link between financial affluence and willingness to exert effort for rewarding outcomes is crucial, as it may reinforce a cycle where the affluent gain more, while the poor fall increasingly behind. Despite the theoretical, societal, and practical implications of financial state perceptions in the willingness to put in effort into challenging tasks, direct experimental evidence exploring this relationship has been limited.

Recent research suggests that the influence of financial states on individual motivation can manifest through perceptions of resource availability and the concomitant psychological states, such as a sense of control and confidence in achieving desired outcomes 2,[8][9][10][11] . Mullainathan and Shafir's influential theory 12 posits that poverty itself creates a scarcity mindset, leading to suboptimal choices and behaviors 13,14 . For example, financially affluent individuals often benefit from greater resource access, which leads to more frequent goal attainment experiences. This can foster a reinforced belief in their ability to overcome difficulties and realize desired outcomes. In contrast, those experiencing scarcity may be more likely to encounter unfulfilled desires, possibly giving rise to a sense of despair and helplessness that can be a significant barrier to engagement in challenging endeavors. Based on these considerations, we hypothesized that perceived financial affluence is associated with individuals' decisions to pursue and actively engage in more effortful tasks for better outcomes. Furthermore, we predicted that such decisions would result in differences in individuals' total monetary rewards.

To test this hypothesis, we utilized an effort-based decision-making paradigm, which has been widely used in recent studies to measure human motivation, specifically the choose-and solve task (CAST) 15 . In this task, participants chose between solving easy, low-reward problems and difficult, high-reward problems, with difficult problems defined as requiring greater effort. This task quantifies the extent to which individuals are willing to exert cognitive effort in pursuit of monetary gains. Prior research indicates that the decision to allocate effort for rewards are largely influenced by one's perceived trade-off between the cost (i.e., effort) and the anticipated benefit (i.e., reward) [16][17][18][19] . Individuals are more inclined to undertake tasks when the perceived benefits exceed the costs, and vice versa when costs are deemed to outweigh benefits. Given their history of successful goal achievements, financially affluent individuals are likely to develop a learned tendency to place a positive value on effort 5,20 . Consequently, they may perceive the effort required for a task as less demanding and the rewards as more attainable and fulfilling. Supporting this, our recent work has shown that those with greater perceived financial affluence exhibit increased interest when expecting rewarding future events and stronger functional communications between/within the brain regions 21 involved in rewardbased learning 22,23 . Given that interest, as a form of intrinsic motivation, often drives goal-directed behavior and facilitates effort toward desired outcomes 24,25 , the perception of having sufficient financial resources can lead individuals to the choice to take on difficult yet highreward problems.

Specifically, we focused on the direct link between perceived financial affluence and the choice of difficult, high-reward problems, while controlling for the effects of cognitive abilities 3,13,26 . To ensure that our experimental design accurately reflects motivated behavior independent of participants' competence levels, we adjusted task difficulty to maintain a 70% accuracy rate across the trials in the task 15 . Additionally, we considered a range of dispositional variables that are known to be related to motivated behavior, including performance-related anxiety 27,28 , growth mindset 29,30 , regulatory focus [31][32][33] , and self-efficacy [34][35][36] . To control any potential influence of materialistic attitudes in reward-seeking behavior 37,38 , participants' materialism was measured. We also evaluated participants' perceptions of life control and optimism, which could affect overall attitude towards challenging tasks 39,40 . Furthermore, to determine whether the choice of difficult, high-reward problems was driven primarily by perceived financial states rather than the availability of non-financial resources, such as social support, we assessed participants' perceived social support 41 . By controlling for potential confounding factors, including cognitive abilities, dispositional traits, and non-financial resources, we aimed to demonstrate that perceived financial affluence uniquely contributes to the willingness to exert effort in challenging tasks. After testing such relationship, we further examined whether individuals with higher perceived financial affluence, by choosing difficult, high-reward problems, would ultimately accumulate greater total monetary rewards.

div.head: Participants
div.p: All participants were recruited through Prolific (https://www.prolific.com/). Based on a priori power analysis using G*Power 42 , a sample size of 191 was determined to be necessary to detect a moderate effect size (f 2 = 0.2) with 80% power at an alpha level of 0.05 in a correlational study. A total of 210 participants initially participated in the present study, but 18

div.head: Experimental design
div.p: Our study is a cross-sectional design that utilizes a regression model combined with a machine learning algorithm. In this study, we considered perceived financial affluence as the predictor, the probability of choosing difficult, high-reward problems, referred to as Hard Choice Probability (HCP), as the main outcome variable, and control variables of individual differences as covariates. Hereafter, 'difficult problems' refer to difficult, high-reward problems, and 'easy problems' to easy, low-reward problems, unless otherwise specified. To test our hypothesis, we employed CAST 15 , which had been programmed using jsPsych 43 (v. 6.3) to allow participants to conduct the experiment online using their web browsers. Participants had to successfully pass at least 13 out of 15 attention checks embedded in the initial questionnaire session to ensure their engagement. After passing these checks, participants proceeded to CAST, beginning with several practice blocks to familiarize them with the problem format, button keys, and time limits. After completing the task, participants filled out a second questionnaire.

div.head: CAST
div.p: This task consisted of three sequential phases in each trial: the 'choose,' 'solve,' and 'feedback' phases. During the choose phase, participants were asked to choose between two types of problems: an 'easy' (i.e., low effort) one with a reward of 2 cents, or a 'hard' (i.e., high effort) one offering a reward ranging from 2 to 6 cents. In the following solve phase, they solved the chosen problem. Finally, in the feedback phase, participants received information about their problem-solving accuracy and the specific reward amount they earned. In each trial, the domain of the problem was categorized as either 'math' (i.e., arithmetic) or 'word' (i.e., spelling), which remained consistent within each trial. We utilized an extensive pool of problems comprising 1999 math problems and 1858 word problems validated in previous research 15 .

To control for potential influence of participants' problem-solving competence on their choice behavior, we implemented an adaptive staircase procedure 15 . This approach continuously adjusted the difficulty of the hard problems to maintain a targeted accuracy rate of 70%, regardless of the participants' varying levels of competence. The problems were selected from a large pool that was categorized into seven difficulty levels. We achieved calibration using a 2up-1-down staircase method, where the difficulty level increases after two consecutive correct answers and decreases following a single incorrect answer, with the difficulty not falling below level 2. Given the accuracy rate of 70%, hard problems offering over 3 cents presents a higher expected value than that of the easy problems with 2 cents (e.g., a hard problem with 4 cents with a 70% accuracy rate has an expected value of 2.8 cents). Thus, we merged trials where hard problems offer 4, 5, and 6 cents and calculated the proportion of these trials to measure the participants' HCP.

We also varied the trial types presented to participants, which included conditions: 'choice' and 'no-choice,' consistent with previous research 15 . In the 'choice' condition, participants were able to decide between easy and hard options, while in the 'no-choice' condition, they were assigned either an easy or hard problem. The no-choice condition was included to ensure a balanced exposure to both easy and hard problems for all participants, which allows for the calculation of participants' competence and easy problem accuracy. The task consisted of practice word and math problems (12 trials each), decision-making practice (28 trials), and four main blocks, each consisting of 28 trials (20 choice trials and 8 no-choice trials), resulting in a total of 112 main trials.

div.head: Questionnaires
div.p: We assessed participants' perceptions of their financial affluence using the material affluence subscale from the Material and Time Affluence Scale (MATAS) 44 . Participants rated their agreement with statements about their financial situations (e.g., I have had enough money to buy the things that are important to me; I have felt like I'm pretty poor). Performance-related anxiety levels were measured using the short math anxiety rating scale (sMARS) 45 and the test anxiety inventory (TAI) 46 . Additionally, we included the scales measuring individual differences related to motivated behavior: the 'Kind of Person' Implicit Theory Scale (KPIT) 47 to measure a growth vs. fixed mindset, the Regulatory Focus Questionnaire (RFQ) 48 , from which we calculated the delta value between promotion and prevention focus, and the New Generalized Self-Efficacy Scale (NGSE) 49 to measure self-efficacy. We included the Material Values Scale (MVS) 50 as well, to consider a potential influence of materialism on the pursuit of monetary gains. Participants also responded to single-item questions assessing their sense of life control and optimism 10 , asking, 'To what extent do you feel in control of your life?' and 'To what extent do you expect good things to happen in the future?' To further examine the distinct influence of perceived financial versus social resources on HCP, we included the Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS) 41 . Demographic factors, including age, sex, education, income, and subjective socioeconomic status (SES) 51 , were also measured.

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: To test whether perceived financial affluence is associated with HCP, we first conducted Pearson's correlation analyses. We then performed multiple regression analyses to determine if this relationship persists after accounting for the effects of individual differences that we included as control variables. To minimize overfitting and select the most influential factors, we implemented the Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO) regression 52 . This was combined with leave-one-out cross-validation (LOOCV) to enhance predictive accuracy. To examine whether HCP mediates the relationship between perceived financial affluence and total monetary gains, we conducted a mediation analysis using the PROCESS macro 53 , controlling for participants' problem-solving accuracy. For exploratory purposes, we also analyzed the relationship between performance-related anxiety and perceived financial affluence using Pearson's correlation, followed by a mediation analysis between perceived financial affluence, performance-related anxiety, and HCP. Lastly, we tested whether these relationships ultimately result in differences in total monetary gains. For multiple comparison correction for different domains, the False Discovery Rate (FDR) 54 was applied. All statistical tests were two-tailed.

div.head: Participants' choice for difficult, high rewards problems
div.p: In line with the criteria established by a previous study 15 , we excluded participants who scored below 70% accuracy on either easy math or word problems (n = 21). A post hoc power analysis using G*Power 42 indicated a power of 0.76, which was adequate to detect a moderate effect size (f² = 0.2) at an alpha level of 0.05. As noted earlier, the task was designed to continuously adjust the difficulty of the hard problems to maintain a target accuracy rate of 70%. Our data confirmed that participants' accuracy on difficult problems was approximately 70% (average: 64.7 ± 8.1%; math: 61.6 ± 13.9%; word: 67.7 ± 7.8%). For these 171 participants, we calculated the proportion of trials in which they chose difficult problems offering higher rewards of 4, 5, or 6 cents (i.e., HCP). We derived both math and word HCPs from each participant and calculated the average of the two tasks to assess the overall HCP (average HCP: 0.724 ± 0.297; math HCP: 0.643 ± 0.378; word HCP: 0.805 ± 0.301).

div.head: Perceived financial affluence is positively correlated with HCP
div.p: We first examined whether perceived financial affluence is associated with the average HCP. As hypothesized, we observed a significant positive correlation between these variables (r = 0.243, P = 0.001; Fig. 1A). To assess whether this relationship persisted across different domains, we conducted separate correlations of financial affluence with math and word HCPs. In both domains, significant associations were observed (math HCP: r169 = 0.238, corrected P = 0.004; word HCP: r169 = 0.180, corrected P = 0.018; Fig. 1A). Conversely, no significant relationships were found between perceived social support and any HCP measures (average HCP: r169 = -0.084, P = 0.273; math HCP: r169 = -0.127, corrected P = 0.194; word HCP, r169 = -0.006, corrected P = 0.938; Fig. 1B), suggesting the specific involvement of perceptions of financial resources to HCP.

div.head: Perceived financial affluence uniquely contributes to HCP after controlling for potential confounding factors
div.p: We then assessed whether the relationship between perceived financial affluence and HCP remained significant after accounting for the effects of individual differences that we measured as control variables. Multiple regression analyses showed that financial affluence significantly predicted the average HCP, even when controlling for the effects of individual differences (B = 0.010, t155 = 2.651, P = 0.009; Fig. 2A & Table S2). In addition to financial affluence, other factors such as age, sex, and test anxiety also showed associations with the average HCP (age: B = -0.012, t155 = -2.476, P = 0.014; sex: B = -0.123, t155 = -2.773, P = 0.006 [male, HCP↑; female, HCP↓]; test anxiety: B = -0.005, t155 = -2.370, P = 0.019; Fig. 2A & Table S2). Further analyses of both math and word HCPs confirmed the significant relationships with financial affluence (math HCP: B = 0.012, t155 = 2.416, P = 0.017; word HCP: B = 0.009, t155 = 2.063, P = 0.041; Fig. 2B & Table S2). Unexpectedly, perceived social support was negatively related to math HCP (B = -0.005, t155 = -2.087, P = 0.038; Fig. 2B & Table S2).

div.head: Machine learning approach identifies perceived financial affluence as one of the most important predictors of HCP
div.p: After confirming the unique influence of perceived financial affluence on HCP, we applied LASSO regression, combined with LOOCV, to create a more generalized model. Unlike traditional regression, LASSO regression is a regularization method that adds a penalty to shrink less important variable coefficients to zero, thereby selecting only the most relevant predictors. We found that financial affluence, along with performance-related anxiety and demographic factors such as age and sex, emerged as the most influential predictors for both the average HCP (Fig. 3A), and math and word HCPs (Fig. 3B). More specifically, perceived financial affluence emerged as the second most important predictor of the average HCP (Fig. 3A), and as the third most significant predictor of the math and word domains (Fig. 3B). In all three analyses (i.e., average, math, and word domains), perceived financial affluence was one of the predictors retained until the final stage of selection.

div.head: Perceived financial affluence leads to greater total monetary gains via decreased performance-related anxiety and higher HCP
div.p: Next, we investigated whether greater perceived financial affluence yielded increased total monetary gains, via higher HCP. The indirect effect analysis revealed that financially affluent participants achieved higher total gains, and this relationship was mediated by the average HCP (B = 1.107, SE = 0.393, 95% CI [0.3665 to 1.9173]). The indirect effect of financial affluence on total gains via HCP remained significant even when we included math and word HCP separately (math HCP: B = 0.792, SE = 0.344, 95% CI [0.1505 to 1.5100]; word HCP: B = 0.939, SE = 0.407, 95% CI [0.1690 to 1.7839]).

Building on the results from the LASSO regularization as well as the multiple regression analyses, which identified perceived financial affluence and performance-related anxiety as key predictors, we further explored the correlation between these variables and found significant negative relationship between financial affluence and anxiety measures (test anxiety: r169 = -0.227, corrected P = 0.003; math anxiety: r169 = -0.303, corrected P < 0.001; Fig. 4A). Based on these findings, we explored the relationships between financial affluence, test anxiety, and HCP.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Research on how financial resources influence individual motivation and achievement holds significant importance, given its academic, social, and practical implication. Using a carefully designed behavioral task and a machine learning approach, while accounting for a range of individual differences, the present study examined how perceived financial affluence affects the decision to exert effort in achieving rewarding outcomes, irrespective of individuals' cognitive ability. Our findings reveal that individuals with greater financial affluence are more likely to choose difficult yet high-reward problems, resulting in increased monetary gains. These results underscore the crucial role of financial perceptions in motivating individuals to pursue challenging goals, thereby leading them to better outcomes.

In line with previous research that highlights the significance of financial states in economic decision-making [1][2][3]13,55 , our study demonstrates a strong relationship between the two. Specifically, we found that participants with greater perceived financial affluence were likely to choose difficult, high-reward problems, while those with lower financial affluence tended to choose easy, low-reward problems. This pattern was consistently observed across different domains (e.g., math and word) and remained significant even after accounting for diverse individual differences known to affect motivated behavior, as well as demographic factors. This robust link may be explained by participants' subjective valuation of the costs and benefits associated with tasks, given theories of economic decision-making [16][17][18][19] . Individuals with greater financial affluence may view effort as more valuable and less costly, with rewards perceived as more attainable. Conversely, those experiencing financial scarcity may perceive the same effort as more demanding and the potential rewards as uncertain. This disparity may be related to how they approach and respond to challenges. In this context, our findings suggest that perceptions of one's financial states play a critical role in how individuals make decisions involving challenging and demanding tasks for high rewards.

Importantly, participants with greater financial affluence reported significantly lower levels of performance-related anxiety. This finding is particularly noteworthy, given the welldocumented influence of anxiety on decision-making and motivated behavior 15,[55][56][57][58] . One possible explanation is that financial affluence provides a greater sense of stability and security 59 , which may help individuals develop a sense of control and empowerment in their ability to manage potential failures or setbacks and, as a result, experience lower anxiety. In contrast, those with less financial affluence may experience increased anxiety because failures can yield more severe and less controllable consequences. This disparity in anxiety can greatly contribute to the decision to engage in challenging tasks. Indeed, our data revealed a significant relationship between greater financial affluence, lower performance-related anxiety, and a higher likelihood of choosing difficult problems. These findings suggest that financial affluence may directly predict decisions to engage in effortful tasks and also indirectly affect them through varying levels of anxiety.

Furthermore, we observed that the decisions to choose difficult or easy problems resulted in differences in total monetary gains. It should be noted that this was largely driven by the likelihood of choosing difficult problems, regardless of participants' competence levels. In addition, we explored the role of performance-related anxiety in this relationship and found that performance-related anxiety and the probability of choosing difficult problems sequentially mediated the relationship between the perceived financial states and financial outcomes. These results provide a more comprehensive understanding of how financial perceptions are intricately linked to anxiety and decision-making processes, ultimately contributing to financial outcomes. Confirming the well-established link between performance-related anxiety and the willingness to take on challenging tasks 15 , our findings suggest a possible psychological mechanism underlying the link between perceptions of financial affluence and financial outcomes 60 .

Interestingly, the decision to choose difficult problems was predicted by perceived financial states rather than the availability of other resources, such as social support. While social support is well-documented as a crucial factor in key life domains, including stress management 61 , health 62,63 , and well-being 64 , its role in effort-based economic decision-making remains unclear. Our analysis consistently revealed positive associations between financial affluence and the likelihood of choosing difficult problems, whereas social resources did not seem to contribute to such decisions. Unexpectedly, our regression analysis in the math domain showed that individuals with greater social support were less likely to select challenging math problems. These inconsistent results across financial and social domains may be specific to our data. Future research should explore various contexts where financial and social resources exert different effects, such as tasks involving non-monetary rewards, emotional support, or peer evaluations.

Among demographic factors, age and sex were also associated with the decision to choose difficult or easy problems. Specifically, younger participants and males were more likely to choose difficult problems compared to older participants and females. This tendency may be attributed to a greater willingness to take risks [65][66][67] and heightened sensitivity to rewards [68][69][70] , both of which are more often observed in younger individuals and males. Additionally, our data revealed that the link between financial affluence and the willingness to choose difficult problems was numerically larger among male participants (r92 = 0.277, P = 0.009) than among female participants (r79 = 0.227, P = 0.045). This indicates that perceptions of financial states may have a more pronounced influence on males in pursuing challenging goals. These findings highlight the importance of considering demographic factors when developing strategies to enhance effort-based decision-making and performance outcomes.

Overall, the present study demonstrates a robust link between perceived financial affluence and the willingness to allocate effort for rewarding outcomes. Contrary to simple, intuitive expectations, it is not those experiencing financial scarcity, but rather those with a sense of affluence, who are more motivated to pursue and engage in effortful tasks for better outcomes. A positive perception of one's financial situation seems to be closely linked to lower performance-related anxiety, encouraging active engagement in challenging tasks that yield better outcomes. Our findings may offer important insight into the self-reinforcing nature of wealth, where perceived affluence can guide further gains, while feelings of scarcity may lead to falling further behind. Fig. 1. The relationship between perceived financial affluence and the willingness to choose difficult, high-reward problems. We first examined the relationship between perceived financial affluence and the average probability of choosing difficult, high-reward problems over easy, low-reward ones (i.e., HCP). (A) As expected, financial affluence showed a significant positive correlation with the average HCP. To determine if this relationship held across different domains, we conducted separate analyses for math and word HCPs. In both domains, financial affluence was significantly associated with HCP. (B) In contrast, perceptions of social resources (i.e., perceived social support) did not show a significant association with either the average HCP or the math and word HCPs. For different problem domains, adjusted P values were applied. HCP, hard choice probability.

div.head: Fig. 2. The potential confounding factors in the relationship between perceived financial affluence and HCP.
div.p: We conducted multiple regression analyses to determine whether the relationship between perceived financial affluence and HCP remained significant after accounting for various individual differences known to affect motivated behavior. (A) The results showed that financial affluence continued to significantly predict the average HCP, even when controlling for a range of these variables. Additionally, factors such as age, sex, and test anxiety were also associated with the average HCP. (B) Further analyses of both math and word HCPs confirmed their significant relationships with financial affluence. The results are presented by standardized betas and 95% confidence intervals. HCP, hard choice probability; SES, Socioeconomic Status, *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01. Fig. 3. The relationship between perceived financial affluence and HCP using LASSO regularization. To minimize overfitting and enhance predictive accuracy, we implemented LASSO regression, a form of regularization, combined with LOOCV. (A) Perceived financial affluence, along with performance-related anxiety and demographic factors such as age and sex, emerged as key predictors of the average HCP. (B) Further analyses confirmed significant relationships between financial affluence and both math and word HCPs. HCP, hard choice probability; LASSO, least absolute shrinkage and selection operator; LOOCV, leave-one-out cross-validation; SES, Socioeconomic Status. Fig. 4. The relationship between perceived financial affluence, performance-related anxiety, HCP, and total monetary gains. Building on the results from LASSO regularization and multiple regression analyses, which identified perceived financial affluence and performance-related anxiety as key predictors, we examined the correlations among these variables. (A) We found significant negative relationships between financial affluence and both test anxiety and math anxiety. For different anxiety measures, adjusted P values were applied. To further explore these relationships, we conducted mediation analyses. As a result, we found triadic relationships: i) greater financial affluence, higher HCP, and increased total monetary gains and ii) greater financial affluence, lower performance-related anxiety, and higher HCP (see Results). (B) To gain a more comprehensive understanding, we included these four variables in the model. The mediation analyses showed that performance-related anxiety and HCP sequentially mediated the relationship between financial affluence and total monetary gains. HCP, hard choice probability. *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01, ***P < 0.001.

figure.figDesc: First, we examined whether test anxiety mediated the relationship between financial affluence and HCP. Results supported the mediation effect of test anxiety (average HCP: B = 0.003, SE = 0.001, 95% CI [0.0004 to 0.0054]; math HCP: B = 0.003, SE = 0.002, 95% CI [0.0003 to 0.0066]; word HCP: B = 0.002, SE = 0.001, 95% CI [0.0002 to 0.0048]). Math anxiety also mediated the relationship between financial affluence and math HCP (B = 0.004, SE = 0.002, 95% CI [0.0010 to 0.0068]). Putting these relationships together, we tested an indirect effect model in which the effect of financial affluence on total gains is sequentially mediated via test anxiety and HCP. The indirect model significantly explained our data (average HCP: B = 0.325, SE = 0.177, 95% CI [0.0354 to 0.7273]; math HCP: B = 0.254, SE = 0.144, 95% CI [0.0283 to 0.5857]; word HCP: B = 0.237, SE = 0.138, 95% CI [0.0272 to 0.5623]). A similar effect was found when we included math anxiety instead of test anxiety (B = 0.312, SE = 0.136, 95% CI [0.0864 to 0.6170]; Fig. 4B).

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This study was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT) (grant no. 2021R1C1C2008426 to W.-G.S.).

div.head: Data and code availability
div.p: The data and code for analyses will be shared upon acceptance at https://osf.io/2bjxp/.

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: Won-Gyo Shin (Conceptualization, Study design, Investigation, Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing-original draft, Writing-review and editing, Project administration, Funding Acquisition), Kyoung Whan Choe (Study design, Methodology), Jeongyeol Ahn (Study design, Methodology), Kimberly Lewis Meidenbauer (Study design, Writing-review and editing), Sunhae Sul (Study design, Methodology, Writing-review and editing, Supervision).

div.head: Declaration of interests
div.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
